comment info:
I notice that the states that are highly populated, such as California, New York, and Pennsylvania also have more deaths due to air pollution that other states. I also notice states closer to the center-west of the country have fewer deaths, with the exception of California, while those on the east side of the country are worse off with air pollution.

I wonder why South Dakota has so much out of state pollution compared to the states around it. The only state around South Dakota that creates more pollution that it receives is Minnesota, and the other states that border Minnesota (North Dakota and Iowa) don't receive nearly as much pollution as S.D.

This graph has a significant impact on me and my my community because the data is taken from a real analysis of air pollution in the current US. It shows how much air pollution is in the US by state, and can help me understand which states to be more cautious in, and how much air pollution is in my state.

The maps show the amount of air pollution in each of the US states, as well as how much is from neighboring states vs how much is created within the state. A catchy title would be: "The Devastating Effect of Air Pollution on the United States."

name: Ashrita
comment info:
1. After looking closely at the 2 graphs, I noticed that number of air pollution related deaths usually corresponds with the population of a state. For example, New York has a high population, and therefore has a higher death rate. A state like Utah, however, has a less population rate and therefore has a lower death rate. I also noticed that states on the coastline tend to have more in-state deaths.

2.  Something that I wonder about this graph is why does a highly populated state like New York have more out of state air pollution when it is so highly populated, and is known for its many buildings and transportation, which contribute to in-state pollution?

3.  Pollution has a high impact on humans and our communities. It impacts our health as well as other living beings' health as well. It also contributes to global warming and is overall negative for the environment.

4. These 2 maps show a connection between population and  pollution. It also shows that for some states, the majority of air pollution related deaths aren't even from in-state, and that pollution can spread to other states as well. A catchy title for this could be "Pollution has no Boundaries; Affecting American Lives from Out of State."

However, the number of in and out-of-state pollution sources is fairly evenly distributed. There seems to be a higher occurrence of in-state pollution sources on the West coast compared to the East coast. 

2. The first thing I wonder is why neither Alaska nor Hawaii is on these maps, as it would be interesting to know their stats. I wonder why there are so many more in-state pollution sources on the West coast, as I would have thought pollution emissions among the two coasts are fairly similar. I also wonder what the main sources of in and out-of-state pollution are. 

3. This affects my community as I live in New Hampshire which has a moderate amount of air pollution-related deaths, meaning the health of those around me is in danger. The bottom map also tells me that much of this pollution comes from out-of-state sources. It would be interesting to find out what my community is doing to try and combat these pollution sources.

Headline: "Danger in the Air: Pollution-Related Deaths Across the United States."

replies.name: S
replies.comment info: @Hannah I wonder if the higher proportions of in-state air pollution on the West Coast might be due to the jet stream. This major air current flows from the west to the east, so it would carry air pollution in that direction. States directly on the West Coast such as California have no land further west than them, so it makes sense that the majority of their air pollution would come from in-state. It would be interesting to see whether some pollution in the East could be traced all the way back the a West Coast state.

name: Moderator Kathy
comment info:
Hi Math Buddies and Graph Analyzers,
Did you know that we can only talk about correlation when the variables are all quantitative, not categorical?  If any of the variables are categorical, like the state, we can only talk about an association.  But, we can consider the correlation between quantitative variables such as the population density of a state and the death rate per 10,000 residents.  What type of correlation would you expect between those?
